metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: R Matrices
Matrices
A matrix is a two dimensional data set with columns and rows.
content.html: A matrix is a two dimensional data set with columns and rows.

content.text: A column is a vertical representation of data, while a row is a horizontal representation of data.
content.html: A column is a vertical representation of data, while a row is a horizontal representation of data.

content.text: A matrix can be created with the matrix() function. Specify the nrow and ncol parameters to get the amount of rows and columns:
content.html: A matrix can be created with the matrix() function. Specify the nrow and ncol parameters to get the amount of rows and columns:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
# Create a matrixthismatrix <- matrix(c(1,2,3,4,5,6), nrow = 3, ncol = 2)# Print the 
  matrixthismatrix

content.code:
# Create a matrixthismatrix <- matrix(c(1,2,3,4,5,6), nrow = 3, ncol = 2)# Print the
matrixthismatrix

syntax_highlighting.text:
# Create a matrixthismatrix <- matrix(c(1,2,3,4,5,6), nrow = 3, ncol = 2)# Print the 
  matrixthismatrix

content.code_html:
# Create a matrix
thismatrix <- matrix(c(1,2,3,4,5,6), nrow = 3, ncol = 2)

# Print the matrix
thismatrix

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
# Create a matrixthismatrix <- matrix(c(1,2,3,4,5,6), nrow = 3, ncol = 2)# Print the 
  matrixthismatrix

content.text: Note: Remember the c() function is used to concatenate items together.
content.html: Note: Remember the c() function is used to concatenate items together.

content.text: You can also create a matrix with strings:
content.html: You can also create a matrix with strings:

content.code_html:
thismatrix <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange"), nrow = 2, ncol = 2)

thismatrix

content.text: Access Matrix Items
You can access the items by using [ ] brackets. The first number "1" in the bracket specifies the row-position, while the second number "2" specifies the column-position:
content.html: You can access the items by using [ ] brackets. The first number "1" in the bracket specifies the row-position, while the second number "2" specifies the column-position:

content.code_html:
thismatrix <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange"), nrow = 2, ncol = 2)

thismatrix[1, 2]

content.text: The whole row can be accessed if you specify a comma after the number in the bracket:
content.html: The whole row can be accessed if you specify a comma after the number in the bracket:

content.code_html:
thismatrix <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange"), nrow = 2, ncol = 2)

thismatrix[2,]

content.text: The whole column can be accessed if you specify a comma before the number in the bracket:
content.html: The whole column can be accessed if you specify a comma before the number in the bracket:

content.code_html:
thismatrix <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange"), nrow = 2, ncol = 2)

thismatrix[,2]

content.text: Access More Than One Row
More than one row can be accessed if you use the c() function:
content.html: More than one row can be accessed if you use the c() function:

content.code_html:
thismatrix <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange","grape", "pineapple", "pear", "melon", "fig"), nrow = 3, ncol = 3)

thismatrix[c(1,2),]

content.text: Access More Than One Column
More than one column can be accessed if you use the c() function:
content.html: More than one column can be accessed if you use the c() function:

content.code_html:
thismatrix <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange","grape", "pineapple", "pear", "melon", "fig"), nrow = 3, ncol = 3)

thismatrix[, c(1,2)]

content.text: Add Rows and Columns
Use the cbind() function to add additional columns in a Matrix:
content.html: Use the cbind() function to add additional columns in a Matrix:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
thismatrix <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange","grape", 
  "pineapple", "pear", "melon", "fig"), nrow = 3, ncol = 3)newmatrix <- 
  cbind(thismatrix, c("strawberry", "blueberry", "raspberry"))
  # Print the new matrix
  newmatrix

content.code:
thismatrix <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange","grape",
"pineapple", "pear", "melon", "fig"), nrow = 3, ncol = 3)newmatrix <-
cbind(thismatrix, c("strawberry", "blueberry", "raspberry"))
# Print the new matrix
newmatrix

syntax_highlighting.text:
thismatrix <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange","grape", 
 "pineapple", "pear", "melon", "fig"), nrow = 3, ncol = 3)newmatrix <- 
  cbind(thismatrix, c("strawberry", "blueberry", "raspberry"))
 # Print the new matrix
  newmatrix

content.code_html:
thismatrix <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange","grape", "pineapple", "pear", "melon", "fig"), nrow = 3, ncol = 3)

newmatrix <- cbind(thismatrix, c("strawberry", "blueberry", "raspberry"))

# Print the new matrix
 newmatrix

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
thismatrix <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange","grape", 
  "pineapple", "pear", "melon", "fig"), nrow = 3, ncol = 3)newmatrix <- 
  cbind(thismatrix, c("strawberry", "blueberry", "raspberry"))
  # Print the new matrix
  newmatrix

content.text: Note: The cells in the new column must be of the same length as the existing matrix.
content.html: Note: The cells in the new column must be of the same length as the existing matrix.

content.text: Use the rbind() function to add additional rows in a Matrix:
content.html: Use the rbind() function to add additional rows in a Matrix:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
thismatrix <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange","grape", 
  "pineapple", "pear", "melon", "fig"), nrow = 3, ncol = 3)newmatrix <- 
  rbind(thismatrix, c("strawberry", "blueberry", "raspberry"))
  # Print the new matrix
  newmatrix

content.code:
thismatrix <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange","grape",
"pineapple", "pear", "melon", "fig"), nrow = 3, ncol = 3)newmatrix <-
rbind(thismatrix, c("strawberry", "blueberry", "raspberry"))
# Print the new matrix
newmatrix

syntax_highlighting.text:
thismatrix <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange","grape", 
 "pineapple", "pear", "melon", "fig"), nrow = 3, ncol = 3)newmatrix <- 
  rbind(thismatrix, c("strawberry", "blueberry", "raspberry"))
 # Print the new matrix
  newmatrix

content.code_html:
thismatrix <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange","grape", "pineapple", "pear", "melon", "fig"), nrow = 3, ncol = 3)

newmatrix <- rbind(thismatrix, c("strawberry", "blueberry", "raspberry"))

# Print the new matrix
 newmatrix

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
thismatrix <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange","grape", 
  "pineapple", "pear", "melon", "fig"), nrow = 3, ncol = 3)newmatrix <- 
  rbind(thismatrix, c("strawberry", "blueberry", "raspberry"))
  # Print the new matrix
  newmatrix

content.text: Note: The cells in the new row must be of the same length as the existing matrix.
content.html: Note: The cells in the new row must be of the same length as the existing matrix.

content.text: Remove Rows and Columns
Use the c() function to remove rows and columns in a Matrix:
content.html: Use the c() function to remove rows and columns in a Matrix:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
thismatrix <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange", "mango", "pineapple"), 
  nrow = 3, ncol =2)
  #Remove the first row and the first columnthismatrix <- thismatrix[-c(1), -c(1)]
  thismatrix
#Remove the first row and the first column

content.code:
thismatrix <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange", "mango", "pineapple"),
nrow = 3, ncol =2)
#Remove the first row and the first columnthismatrix <- thismatrix[-c(1), -c(1)]
thismatrix

syntax_highlighting.text:
thismatrix <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange", "mango", "pineapple"), 
  nrow = 3, ncol =2)
 #Remove the first row and the first columnthismatrix <- thismatrix[-c(1), -c(1)]
  thismatrix
#Remove the first row and the first column

content.code_html:
thismatrix <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange", "mango", "pineapple"), nrow = 3, ncol =2)

#Remove the first row and the first column
thismatrix <- thismatrix[-c(1), -c(1)]

thismatrix

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
thismatrix <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange", "mango", "pineapple"), 
  nrow = 3, ncol =2)
  #Remove the first row and the first columnthismatrix <- thismatrix[-c(1), -c(1)]
  thismatrix
#Remove the first row and the first column

content.text: Check if an Item Exists
To find out if a specified item is present in a matrix, use the %in% operator:
content.html: To find out if a specified item is present in a matrix, use the %in% operator:

content.code_html:
thismatrix <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange"), nrow = 2, ncol = 2)

"apple" %in% thismatrix

content.text: Number of Rows and Columns
Use the dim() function to find the number of rows and columns in a Matrix:
content.html: Use the dim() function to find the number of rows and columns in a Matrix:

content.code_html:
thismatrix <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange"), nrow = 2, ncol = 2)

dim(thismatrix)

content.text: Matrix Length
Use the length() function to find the dimension of a Matrix:
content.html: Use the length() function to find the dimension of a Matrix:

content.code_html:
thismatrix <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange"), nrow = 2, ncol = 2)

length(thismatrix)

content.text: Total cells in the matrix is the number of rows multiplied by number of columns.
content.html: Total cells in the matrix is the number of rows multiplied by number of columns.

content.text: In the example above: Dimension = 2*2 = 4 .
content.html: In the example above: Dimension = 2*2 = 4.

content.text: Loop Through a Matrix
You can loop through a Matrix using a for loop. The loop will start at the first row, moving right:
content.html: You can loop through a Matrix using a for loop. The loop will start at the first row, moving right:

content.code_html:
thismatrix <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "orange"), nrow = 2, ncol = 2)

for (rows in 1:nrow(thismatrix)) {
  for (columns in 1:ncol(thismatrix)) {
    print(thismatrix[rows, columns])
  }
}

content.text: Combine two Matrices
Again, you can use the rbind() or cbind() function to combine two or more matrices together:
content.html: Again, you can use the rbind() or cbind() function to combine two or more matrices together:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
# Combine matricesMatrix1 <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", 
  "grape"), nrow = 2, ncol = 2)Matrix2 <- matrix(c("orange", "mango", 
  "pineapple", "watermelon"), nrow = 2, ncol = 2)# Adding it as a rows
  Matrix_Combined <- rbind(Matrix1, Matrix2)Matrix_Combined
  # Adding it as a columnsMatrix_Combined <- cbind(Matrix1, Matrix2)
  Matrix_Combined

content.code:
# Combine matricesMatrix1 <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry",
"grape"), nrow = 2, ncol = 2)Matrix2 <- matrix(c("orange", "mango",
"pineapple", "watermelon"), nrow = 2, ncol = 2)# Adding it as a rows
Matrix_Combined <- rbind(Matrix1, Matrix2)Matrix_Combined
# Adding it as a columnsMatrix_Combined <- cbind(Matrix1, Matrix2)
Matrix_Combined

syntax_highlighting.text:
# Combine matricesMatrix1 <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", 
 "grape"), nrow = 2, ncol = 2)Matrix2 <- matrix(c("orange", "mango", 
 "pineapple", "watermelon"), nrow = 2, ncol = 2)# Adding it as a rows
  Matrix_Combined <- rbind(Matrix1, Matrix2)Matrix_Combined
 # Adding it as a columnsMatrix_Combined <- cbind(Matrix1, Matrix2)
  Matrix_Combined

content.code_html:
# Combine matrices
Matrix1 <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", "grape"), nrow = 2, ncol = 2)
Matrix2 <- matrix(c("orange", "mango", "pineapple", "watermelon"), nrow = 2, ncol = 2)

# Adding it as a rows
 Matrix_Combined <- rbind(Matrix1, Matrix2)
Matrix_Combined

# Adding it as a columns
Matrix_Combined <- cbind(Matrix1, Matrix2)
Matrix_Combined

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
# Combine matricesMatrix1 <- matrix(c("apple", "banana", "cherry", 
  "grape"), nrow = 2, ncol = 2)Matrix2 <- matrix(c("orange", "mango", 
  "pineapple", "watermelon"), nrow = 2, ncol = 2)# Adding it as a rows
  Matrix_Combined <- rbind(Matrix1, Matrix2)Matrix_Combined
  # Adding it as a columnsMatrix_Combined <- cbind(Matrix1, Matrix2)
  Matrix_Combined
